{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3419003,"name":"Doug Kavner","username":"dkavner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dkavner/{size}/207188_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-29T05:37:18.715Z","cooked":"

@kiettyyyy The new VH-109 Radios only allow configuration of a team number. They don’t support a robot name in the SSID. This is a safety hazard for teams with multiple robots, such as ours. I was once run over because a student connected to the wrong robot from another room. As a result, it is now drilled into all of our drivers and technicians that they never connect to a robot without first verifying the name and this is not possible with the VH-109 radios. Using phantom team numbers is not an acceptable solution. Our students know our four robots by name, not by made up numbers.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":62,"updated_at":"2024-08-29T05:37:18.715Z","reply_count":4,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":172,"reads":1003,"readers_count":1002,"score":1200.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":470437,"topic_slug":"vh-109-radio-hazard","display_username":"Doug Kavner","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54568,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/vh-109-radio-hazard/470437/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":8},{"id":"-1","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":10,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3419005,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-29T05:47:24.889Z","cooked":"

Known, discussed, and there is a fix in process.

[FRC Blog] New Radios at 2024 FIRST Championship General Forum
Just so everyone knows and we can put this particular topic to rest We decided to go down the route of a user defined suffix that is limited in length, alphanumeric and UTF-8 encoded. This suffix applies to BOTH the 6 GHz and 2.4 GHz SSIDs. For example, the configured team is 1538, the suffix is vivid. The resulting 6 GHz SSID will be 1538-vivid, the resulting 2.4 GHz SSID will be FRC-1538-vivid. This feature set will be included in the v1.2 release. It will not be in the 202…

I don’t consider waiting until 2026 to be an acceptable solution. Our students are connecting to these radios now. This is a safety issue.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":62,"updated_at":"2024-08-29T05:51:53.965Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":930,"readers_count":929,"score":281.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":470437,"topic_slug":"vh-109-radio-hazard","display_username":"Doug Kavner","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":4212,"username":"EricH","name":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54568,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/vh-109-radio-hazard/470437/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5},{"id":"-1","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":9,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3419012,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-29T06:09:19.799Z","cooked":"
  1. I don’t see a single place in that post where 2026 is noted, stated, implied, or otherwise noted as the release timeline for the 1.2 firmware. Given Kiet’s responses later in the thread, I would expect it to be available for 2025, but not the default (because the radios were not shipped with it).
  2. Your students are fully capable of learning alternative processes. Equipment changes, process changes. If you got a new machine for the shop, you wouldn’t operate it the exact same way as the machine it replaced, would you? I thought not.
  3. There is a reason for the radio being set up the way it is. Go up that thread instead of down, there’s a security risk that MUST be mitigated, or there’s a risk of losing the certification (and thus the ability to lose the radio). That security risk is being mitigated by limiting the ability to set the SSID. Therefore, limited SSID setting is a requirement that you must deal with. (I’ll link that post set if you can’t find it.)
  4. Kiet is actively working on the VH113 radio and a VH109 “act like VH113” firmware. I would strongly suggest that that takes higher priority–if those don’t work, the events are going to be problematic at best, and working with multiple robots in team shops will be harder, respectively.
  5. The issue is known and being worked on. Impatience will not get it done any faster.

Seems like you are saying the semantics of knowing your robots by name and not temporarily changing to using numbers is too annoying for you to address a saftey problem? Weird hill to die on. Might need to take a step back and address your priorities a bit.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":62,"updated_at":"2024-08-29T11:35:47.229Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":819,"readers_count":818,"score":553.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":470437,"topic_slug":"vh-109-radio-hazard","display_username":"John Fogarty","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":54568,"username":"dkavner","name":"Doug Kavner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dkavner/{size}/207188_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":25}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12688,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/vh-109-radio-hazard/470437/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":21},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":25,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3419044,"name":"Mr. Siefen | 453","username":"kingc95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kingc95/{size}/226662_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-29T12:12:34.223Z","cooked":"
dkavner:

I was once run over because a student connected to the wrong robot from another room. As a result, it is now drilled into all of our drivers and technicians that they never connect to a robot without first verifying the name

While this is a good strategy, shouldn’t the first steps after connecting be to check the status of the RSL of the intended robot and if it is functioning as expected?

Before using any controller inputs or doing anything dangerous, when you first connect you should do a short test teleop enable/disable and make sure the RSL starts to flash and stops as expected. If so you know you are the one starting and stopping the robot you are physically looking at. If you are enabling teleop and the RSL in front of you stays steady, you must be connected to a different robot that you cannot see. This is unsafe and therefore you should stop it immediately and disconnect.

The other benefit of this is to make sure you can stop the robot on demand as you expect as well. No good starting the thing if you can’t stop it later. Always check this works before you start actually practicing/testing.

Wireless networks on robots can reach far away and it’s not safe to just assume the SSID has never changed. What if someone swapped radios because one died in an emergency and it was never renamed? If you are using multiple robots consistently, then consider adding additional safety steps in case the SSID is not reliable (i.e. now)

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":62,"updated_at":"2024-08-29T12:14:34.540Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":800,"readers_count":799,"score":330.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":470437,"topic_slug":"vh-109-radio-hazard","display_username":"Mr. Siefen | 453","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":9}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":20632,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mr. Siefen"},"post_url":"/t/vh-109-radio-hazard/470437/6","custom_user_title":"Mr. Siefen","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":9}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":9,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3419046,"name":"tkchan","username":"tkchan","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/t/ee59a6/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-08-29T12:24:29.497Z","cooked":"

This wont solve all problem but our plan was going to flash all the radios that we have to a known name for each of them along with our team number and keep them for inhouse use. Might need to have some ethernet switches on hand as well if you need them for co-processors (which you probably have already).

I will miss not seeing “swervy mcswerve” in my networks for our test bed robot.

Two words…
“Amongus Swerve”

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":62,"updated_at":"2024-08-29T14:06:06.029Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":670,"readers_count":669,"score":194.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":470437,"topic_slug":"vh-109-radio-hazard","display_username":"John Fogarty","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":8002,"username":"Akash_Rastogi","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/akash_rastogi/{size}/169937_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":12688,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/vh-109-radio-hazard/470437/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4},{"id":"laughing","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3419090,"name":"","username":"LPryor","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lpryor/{size}/220287_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-29T15:37:06.901Z","cooked":"

New radios are expensive and not every off season event is using them. Seems to me to make sense to pause upgrading everything in the short term. Leave your other robots on the legacy system until there is a workaround or simply use a different team number for development or research bots.

Agreed! Another solution is only keep the main robot on the new radio and other platforms on old radios. Save a little $$.

To the OG poster, don’t rely on others to make your build space safe. Be creative and find a solution that works for your team.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":62,"updated_at":"2024-08-29T15:46:34.117Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":629,"readers_count":628,"score":220.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":470437,"topic_slug":"vh-109-radio-hazard","display_username":"Cory Walters","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":55309,"username":"LPryor","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/lpryor/{size}/220287_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22243,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/vh-109-radio-hazard/470437/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3419135,"name":"Doug Kavner","username":"dkavner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dkavner/{size}/207188_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-29T16:37:09.377Z","cooked":"

This is a recipe for a workable system, but not a safe system. Everyone knows the names of our robots. We can’t count on students to know phantom team numbers by heart. They have been using the same name for some robots for 4 years. Being run over by a robot changes your priorities.

Cory_Walters:

Agreed! Another solution is only keep the main robot on the new radio and other platforms on old radios. Save a little $$.

This is of course what we will need to do. However, it still sacrifices safety in a manner for which we can’t compensate because students will be developing the rote memory of not checking the robot name when connecting, which is what we have worked so hard to prevent.

kingc95:

shouldn’t the first steps after connecting be to check the status of the RSL of the intended robot and if it is functioning as expected?

Before using any controller inputs or doing anything dangerous, when you first connect you should do a short test teleop enable/disable and make sure the RSL starts to flash and stops as expected. If so you know you are the one starting and stopping the robot you are physically looking at. If you are enabling teleop and the RSL in front of you stays steady, you must be connected to a different robot that you cannot see. This is unsafe and therefore you should stop it immediately and disconnect.

I would never teach a student to test proper connectivity by enabling a robot. Enabling is a dangerous operation, especially during development. You have no idea what the robot might do. We take great care to make our robots not move anything when enabled, but that is only after we get the bugs out. Even now, when we enable our 5940 clone, the swerve modules immediately rotate. We don’t allow that in the code we develop, but we have lifted 5940’s code and we don’t have time to retrofit such protections at the moment

Wireless networks on robots can reach far away and it’s not safe to just assume the SSID has never changed. What if someone swapped radios because one died in an emergency and it was never renamed? If you are using multiple robots consistently, then consider adding additional safety steps in case the SSID is not reliable (i.e. now)

Part of our procedures is to always set the SSID when swapping radios.

How many “phantom team numbers” are you expecting to deal with? When I was a student dealing with the D-Link routers, it was easy enough to remember that the competition bot got 4646 and the practice bot got 6464.

","post_number":17,"post_type":1,"posts_count":62,"updated_at":"2024-08-29T17:19:08.797Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":500,"readers_count":499,"score":155.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":470437,"topic_slug":"vh-109-radio-hazard","display_username":"bobbysq","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":54568,"username":"dkavner","name":"Doug Kavner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dkavner/{size}/207188_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":28014,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"he/him"},"post_url":"/t/vh-109-radio-hazard/470437/17","custom_user_title":"he/him","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3419158,"name":"Doug Kavner","username":"dkavner","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dkavner/{size}/207188_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-29T17:30:05.030Z","cooked":"
EricH:
  1. I don’t see a single place in that post where 2026 is noted, stated, implied, or otherwise noted as the release timeline for the 1.2 firmware. Given Kiet’s responses later in the thread, I would expect it to be available for 2025, but not the default (because the radios were not shipped with it).

I assumed 2026 because it sounded like it wasn’t coming for the 2025 build season. As you said, we don’t really know when it will be available.

  1. Your students are fully capable of learning alternative processes. Equipment changes, process changes. If you got a new machine for the shop, you wouldn’t operate it the exact same way as the machine it replaced, would you? I thought not.

Of course they can learn alternative processes to make things work. That doesn’t mean that they are safe processes, especially when what they fundamentally need isn’t supported by the radio.

  1. There is a reason for the radio being set up the way it is. Go up that thread instead of down, there’s a security risk that MUST be mitigated, or there’s a risk of losing the certification (and thus the ability to lose the radio). That security risk is being mitigated by limiting the ability to set the SSID. Therefore, limited SSID setting is a requirement that you must deal with. (I’ll link that post set if you can’t find it.)

Thanks for the explanation. My response from a safety engineering perspective is that the new radios shouldn’t have been introduced until they were as safe as the radios that they are replacing.

  1. Kiet is actively working on the VH113 radio and a VH109 “act like VH113” firmware. I would strongly suggest that that takes higher priority–if those don’t work, the events are going to be problematic at best, and working with multiple robots in team shops will be harder, respectively.
  2. The issue is known and being worked on. Impatience will not get it done any faster.

“Safety First” is a nice buzzword, until it becomes inconvenient. I greatly appreciate the efforts of Kiet to improve our radio situation and I realize that he probably wasn’t aware of the safety implications of not being able to set the SSID. The purpose of this post is to raise that awareness.

","post_number":18,"post_type":1,"posts_count":62,"updated_at":"2024-08-29T17:30:05.030Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":509,"readers_count":508,"score":106.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":470437,"topic_slug":"vh-109-radio-hazard","display_username":"Doug Kavner","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":54568,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/vh-109-radio-hazard/470437/18","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3419166,"name":"Eric Ward","username":"bathtubed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-29T17:53:09.653Z","cooked":"
dkavner:

Part of our procedures is to always set the SSID when swapping radios.

It seems you’ve drawn a circle around the processes your team uses and called it “safe,” and defined any thing alternative to that “unsafe.”

I don’t see how it’s unreasonable that students memorized robot names and will never, ever mix them up, while it’s impossible for them to do the same with robot numbers.
Like sure you can say part of your procedure is to always set the SSID when swapping radios but that isn’t actually enforceable right, someone could very easily swap 2 radios and the SSIDs are effectively swapped without anyone knowing.

What if a student misclicks the wrong SSID in their PCs wifi tray? This could feasibly happen.

Someone suggested a very robust practice of actually teaching students to read RSLs, something people should be very familiar with in a safety context, and which would have prevented you from being run over in your initial example, but you reject that as being unsafe.
Should this be your only way of checking you’re connected to the right robot? No, but it should still be something that everyone working with the robot knows and understands.

Personally, I think if you want to actually be safe, make them check a camera stream, blink a talon, check the status of a sensor. Reboot the rio/robot code and watch the status lights.
There’s lots of ways you can visually confirm that the robot you’re connected to is the one you’re looking at without enabling the robot or relying on memorizing SSIDs.

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":62,"updated_at":"2024-08-29T17:53:09.653Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":16,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":472,"readers_count":471,"score":454.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":470437,"topic_slug":"vh-109-radio-hazard","display_username":"Eric Ward","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":22}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":35208,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3637 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/vh-109-radio-hazard/470437/19","custom_user_title":"3637 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":21},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":22,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3419178,"name":"Andrew Lawrence","username":"Andrew_L","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/andrew_l/{size}/270442_2.png","created_at":"2024-08-29T18:00:26.589Z","cooked":"
dkavner:

I was once run over because a student connected to the wrong robot from another room.

Why were you standing next to a powered robot, and why were you surprised that it moved? If safety is a priority, you should assume all powered robots will move unexpectedly at a moment’s notice, keep yourself a safe distance from powered robots at all times, and ideally keep powered robots in an enclosed or separated space away from hazards. Even outside of accidental enables, faulty wiring or control system components could route electricity to motors unexpectedly and cause unplanned motion. Always assume a powered robot will move.
